summary_markdown:
# About Quartet Health

Quartet Health is a value-based behavioral healthcare company founded on January 1, 2014, and headquartered in New York, United States [(Crunchbase, 2024)](https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/quartet-health). The company focuses on expanding access to high-quality care for individuals with behavioral health needs, including serious mental illness (SMI). Quartet Health operates in 39 states and partners with health plans, health systems, and community mental health centers to provide comprehensive behavioral health solutions [(Quartet Health on 2024-09-20)](https://www.quartethealth.com/).

Quartet Health's services include care enablement and delivery, where they offer end-to-end behavioral health solutions that identify, engage, and care for patients. They collaborate with various health plans and systems to connect patients with high-quality providers, including their own medical group [(Quartet Health on 2024-09-20)](https://www.quartethealth.com/).

The company primarily operates in a B2B model, serving clients such as health plans, health systems, and community mental health centers [(Quartet Health on 2024-09-20)](https://www.quartethealth.com/). Quartet Health is backed by prominent investors, including Oak HC/FT, GV (formerly Google Ventures), F-Prime Capital Partners, and Centene Corporation, which indicates strong financial support and confidence in its business model [(Built In NYC, 2023)](https://www.builtinnyc.com/job/actuary/286127).

Quartet Health has raised a total of $265 million in funding, with the most recent round being $51 million on February 17, 2022 [(Crunchbase, 2024)](https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/quartet-health).

# Key Personnel

- **Christina Mainelli**: CEO of Quartet Health. She has emphasized the importance of integrated care, particularly for individuals with SMI, highlighting the interconnectedness of physical and mental health needs [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).
- **Dr. Michael J. Lipp**: Chief Medical Officer. He brings expertise from his previous role as CMO of the CMS Innovation Center, adding credibility to the company's initiatives in value-based care [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).
- **Karen Mitchell**: Chief Growth Officer, announced in February 2024 [(Quartet Health, 2024-02-15)](https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/quartet-health-announces-karen-mitchell-as-chief-growth-officer-302062185.html).

# News

## Recent Developments

- **Whole Health Program Launch**: On March 19, 2024, Quartet Health announced the launch of its Whole Health program in partnership with Clover Health. This program is designed to provide a comprehensive care delivery solution for patients with SMI by integrating physical and behavioral health services. The initiative aims to address the fragmented healthcare system that often leads to poor outcomes for these patients [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).

- **Partnership with Arbital Health**: Quartet Health partnered with Arbital Health to increase value-based mental healthcare, as reported on October 17, 2024 [(Mobi Health News, 2024-10-17)](https://www.mobihealthnews.com/news/arbital-health-quartet-health-partner-increase-value-based-mental-healthcare).

## Product Overview

The Whole Health program is a first-of-its-kind initiative that takes accountability for the total cost of care (TCOC) risk on health plans’ most complex members. It provides wraparound care services, including 24/7 access to care, medication support, and coordination of mental and physical health services. This program is particularly focused on underserved populations, addressing the unique needs of patients with SMI who often have multiple chronic conditions and face barriers to accessing care [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).

# Conclusion

Quartet Health is positioned as a leader in the behavioral healthcare space, particularly with its recent launch of the Whole Health program in partnership with Clover Health. The company's commitment to integrated care and addressing the needs of underserved populations reflects a strong alignment with current healthcare trends focused on value-based care. For prospective candidates and investors, Quartet Health represents an opportunity to engage with a forward-thinking organization dedicated to improving health outcomes through innovative solutions.

# Quartet Health Summary

## Company Overview
Quartet Health is a leading value-based behavioral healthcare company focused on expanding access to high-quality care for individuals with behavioral health needs, including serious mental illness. The company operates in 39 states and partners with health plans, health systems, and community mental health centers to provide comprehensive behavioral health solutions. Their innovative approaches aim to navigate the complex mental health landscape, ensuring that patients receive whole-person care [(Quartet Health on 2024-09-20)](https://www.quartethealth.com/).

## Services and Products
- **Care Enablement and Delivery**: Quartet Health offers end-to-end behavioral health solutions that identify, engage, and care for patients.
- **Partnerships**: They collaborate with various health plans and systems to connect patients with high-quality providers, including their own medical group.

## Customers
Quartet Health serves a diverse range of clients, including:
- Health plans
- Health systems
- Community mental health centers

## Leadership Team and Culture
Quartet Health emphasizes a supportive and inclusive workplace culture. They have established diverse employee resource groups (ERGs) that promote a sense of belonging and reflect their commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI). The company fosters an environment where employees can grow and feel supported, with a focus on kindness and collaboration [(Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion at Quartet on 2021-10-18)](https://www.quartethealth.com/dei/).

## Career Opportunities
Quartet Health is committed to building trusted partnerships and offers a structured onboarding process for new employees. They provide training sessions to help new hires succeed in their roles and encourage a culture of support and growth [(Quartet Health on 2020-05-27)](https://www.quartethealth.com/careers/).

## Security and Privacy
Quartet Health prioritizes the security of sensitive data and adheres to regulatory requirements such as HIPAA and HITECH. They utilize Amazon Web Services (AWS) for secure data storage and processing, ensuring that all data is protected through various security measures [(Quartet Health on 2021-08-06)](https://www.quartethealth.com/security/).

## Conclusion
Quartet Health is dedicated to improving lives through quality behavioral healthcare, with a strong focus on inclusivity, security, and partnership. Their commitment to DEI and employee support reflects their mission to provide comprehensive care to those in need.
page_markdowns:
# [Quartet Health on 2024-09-20](https://www.quartethealth.com/)
Quartet Health is an industry-leading value-based behavioral healthcare company. We expand access to and deliver high-quality care for people with behavioral health needs, including serious mental illness. Quartet’s care enablement and delivery offerings seek to improve the lives of patients by providing whole, human, behavioral health care to those in need.

Our innovative approaches to navigating the complex mental health landscape enable us to identify, engage, and care for patients and deliver an end-to-end behavioral health solution. We are a trusted partner of health plans, health systems, and community mental health centers that serve patients in 39 states across the country.

# [Quartet Health on 2021-08-06](https://www.quartethealth.com/security/)
At Quartet, we recognize the highly sensitive nature of data entrusted to us by our partners. We also recognize the regulatory requirements set forth by HIPAA / HITECH and industry best practices and standards (e.g., AICPA Trust Services Principles and ISO27001/ 2) and strive to meet and exceed those requirements. The goal of this Security Statement is to ensure transparency regarding our security practices, and to help reassure you that your data is appropriately protected.

You may report security issues to us at [email protected]

Quartet utilizes Amazon Web Services (“AWS”) in order to take advantage of the elasticity, reliability and security of the AWS Infrastructure as a cloud service.

All data is stored and processed through AWS’ certified-secure facilities:

AWS hosting facilities are SOC Type 1 & 2 certified and certified to meet ISO standards

AWS hosting facilities accessible only by biometric scanning

24/ 7 monitoring by security guards

24/ 7 video surveillance

Thanks for your interest in Quartet!

We've received your details, and will let you know when we're in your area.

To learn more about your mental health, visit your Resources page.

Diving into the role

Getting to know us

Meet with a variety of team members on-site or virtually and hear more about life at Quartet. This is about learning what it'd be like for all of us to work together.

Joining the team

Quartet was founded in 2014 and is based in  New York, United States.

reviews.cons: Lots to learn. Multiple interlocking systems, lots of knowledge. Broad responsibilities. Good if you are easily bored.
reviews.pros: Good company. They care about their employees. What they do helps the world. Good pay and benefits. Unlimited PTO you can actually use. Great diversity.

reviews.advice: communicate expectations
reviews.cons: work until 6 pm twice a week
reviews.pros: Decent insurance benefits are available

reviews.advice: Offer coaching to all associates in C-suite, Senior Leadership, and in Executive Support to better align messaging and execution, as well as to provide cohesive understanding of business etiquette.
reviews.cons:
- There are some associates who do not pull their weight in comparison to others (same as everywhere).
 - There are a handful of developing leaders who do not credit contributors as they should, which causes occasional resentment.
 - The business is constantly changing, resulting in burnout for some associates.
reviews.pros:
- The vast majority of people working at Quartet Health are friendly, kind, and extremely hard-working. 
 - Leadership is dedicated to growing a successful company while improving the lives of the people in the Behavioral Health population. 
 - The salaries/benefits are competitive.
 - The teamwork in my area is probably the strongest and most supportive of any company I have ever worked at during my career.

reviews.advice: Not worth wasting the words. They don't care. This will be explained as just another "disgruntled former employee."
reviews.cons:
EVERYTHING else.
No co culture. Killed when they ousted the former CEO. ERGs are defunct - they laid off everyone involved over the course of two years. No one cares enough about the company or culture to try.
Management decreases benefits about every 6 months. Raises are paltry. Everything from company holidays to vacation time constantly stripped back for non-leadership employees. Ask someone about the Juneteenth or maternity leave debates. It will tell you everything you need to know.
Continue to claim "start up" status only because they are floundering for a strategy they can monetize. Total lack a consistent roadmap, because the strategy is changes yearly. 
Ever-increasing workload shoveled on the few employees not laid off with no increase in compensation or titles. Employee stratification undervalues everyone except leadership. Use that that to refuse to compensate employees for the additional work demanded of them.
Commitment to DEI is a lie, especially at the leadership level. All management hiring based on knowing the existing management team. Very white, hetero, male. Don't let the current female CEO fool you.
HR team tries, but they are handcuffed by leadership. As long as an employee is "producing" or part of the leadership circle, bad behavior is excused. Repeat offenders sit on the leadership team, and the people that reported leave rather than fight a losing battle. 
If you want real nightmares, know they laid off people on maternity/paternity leave, and laid off an employee that was literally weeks from her due date. That is the leadership you're getting here.
reviews.pros: Coworkers are some of the best. Dedicated to the mental health of their users.
reviews.summary: The bad reviews are real, no matter what management says

reviews.cons: -The only major con of working here has been some of the uncertainty with lay-offs last year... However, the whole industry experienced similar things, and Quartet has adapted well and is moving forward leaner and stronger than ever, allowing for more runway to "make it." And it seems we finally have the right people on board.
reviews.pros:
-A lot of smart and dedicated people work here. However, the culture is not overly stuffy and there is no air of pretentiousness like at some start-ups / growth stage companies
-The mission of expanding access to quality mental healthcare is at the core of the business and most of the employees care greatly about this
-The work is interesting, as there are multiple product lines and plenty of analytically interesting challenges to overcome, as with any business striving for maturation and sustainable profitability
-The business is fully remote, and work-life balance is good. Even in busy times with long hours for a period of time, the flexibility of being remote to take breaks during the day and get things done later makes it bearable long-term
reviews.summary: Good People, Great Mission, Interesting Work

reviews.cons: Virtual-first working style isn't for everyone, but HR and leadership continue to find ways to foster a strong sense of community. There are regional meet-ups and budget for team building activities.
reviews.pros:
Quartet Health has a very mission & purpose-driven culture. The people who work here are passionate about improving access to quality healthcare for everyone. Each monthly all-employee Town Hall meeting starts with a Patient story to highlight the impact we're making in people's lives. Instances where employees demonstrate our Corporate values are also recognized each meeting.

There has been strong continuity among senior leadership the last few years and they have cast a compelling vision of the future to strengthen alignment at all levels on the pathway forward.
reviews.summary: Great place to make an impact in the communities we serve & grow your career

reviews.advice: Keep up the great work! Continue to listen, be responsive, and value employees, clients, and patients as Quartet continues to grow. Staying flexible to respond to market needs and opportunities will ensure we remain successful.
reviews.cons: Honestly, I can't think of any major downsides to working at Quartet Health.
reviews.pros: Quartet Health is a fantastic place to work, and I get to work with a wonderful group of talented people. My direct leader creates a supportive environment, offering plenty of opportunities for continuous learning and growth, which makes me feel truly valued. The work we do here has a real impact, and it's incredibly rewarding to see the difference we make. Additionally, the senior and executive leadership genuinely listens to us, which is a rare and appreciated quality.
reviews.summary: A Great Place to Work with Amazing People

reviews.cons: Top down approach to management
reviews.pros: Great colleagues to work with

reviews.cons: Change can stress folks out. Its personally not a con for me but I know for others rapid change is difficult.
reviews.pros: The team is great in total. Whether its your direct team or working crossfunctionally, everyone is generally pleasant to work with. Its very flexible, everyone is understanding of work/life balance. Leadership is sharp.

reviews.cons:
-No raise or cost of living adjustment in 2 years
-Do not know how to value employees.
-"Start up culture" (roll out new initiatives, not the best communication, focus on growth-but not on retention)
-Christmas Bonus was a certificate valued up to $20 to a website (options included 1 of the following: a pair of socks, a wick trimmer, wool dryer balls, a bar of fancy chocolate, a few tea bags, a 'boutique' car air freshener, and a few other miscellaneous items)
reviews.pros:
-Meaningful work
-Clinical leadership is solid

reviews.advice: There isn’t any advice the management team hasn’t heard, acknowledged and IGNORED. Its completely pointless to bring anything up because it’s routinely ignored or turned around and blamed on Care Navigation.
reviews.cons:
9/2022 UPDATE: Quartet is now taking away our unlimited PTO and our salaried positions. They are moving all of the Care Navigation/ Customer Support Staff team to hourly positions. They have given us 9 days notice and we will go without full pay while they do this. Quartet Health is the WORST company I have ever worked for. They lie, make up fake laws and only pay or reward upper management. THEY DO NOT CARE ABOUT MENTAL HEALTH AT ALL. 


They continue to advertise “unlimited pto”. However this just isn’t true. If you’re a manager or above then yes, have at it. If you’re on the Care Navigation team or the Customer Support Staff who answer phones they will not give you time off. 
They count literally everyday you are off and have a point system for those who they deem unworthy to use their “unlimited pto”. It’s now the WORST Pto plan I’ve had in 20 years in health care. 

They have also taken our 15 holidays a year and reduced it to 6. Which is well below the National average for holidays allowed per year. 

The management staff have absolutely no idea how difficult the roles are speaking to the patients on a daily basis. The burn out rate is very high due to their unrealistic metrics. Also- most patients are not cared for simply because they have the “wrong” insurance and Quartet doesn’t get paid. This place is a complete waste of time for most patients and employees. If you want to feel like the sludge at the bottom of a pond, join Quartet!
reviews.pros: The pros are pretty simple, you work from home. Which in all honesty isn’t such a pro anymore with so many companies offering this. That’s the only pro.
reviews.summary: Quartet Health; the mental health company that cares NOTHING about mental health!

reviews.advice:
It's a classic case of not taking care of your employees. Leadership has no idea what employees do and how they speak/assist patients all day every day. It is incredibly taxing work. 

Employees talk amongst themselves and morale is incredibly low. Never worked at a place with such low morale as here. They talk about quitting, burnout, and dread of coming into work every day. 

Implement real changes like higher salaries, less micro management, better work life balance, and adjusted metrics. 

The work Quartet does is important but the culture and environment isn't helpful to the mission. 

Bad employee experience = bad patient experience. Quite obvious but this seems like a concept that hasn't yet been realized by leadership.
reviews.cons:
- There's a lot of micro management because they are so focused on metrics. It creates extreme burnout, stress, and overall just a horrible time while at work. The metrics goals are not sustainable and unreachable. 

- The salary is laughable. For the type and amount of work that is required, they do not pay well. People make a lot more doing a lot less elsewhere. 

-The bonuses are also laughable. Almost impossible to attain because it's based on unrealistic goals. You have to work like a robot and still you may not reach them. Yet they wonder why no one's metrics are met. 

- Turnover rate is incredibly high. Management changes, poorly thought out metrics and workflows, and a lot of the jobs themselves are horrible to do. Always understaffed due to high turnover. 

- Out of Touch Leadership: Great lip service but that's about it. Employees are miserable yet leadership thinks everything is great. For Employee Appreciation Day, let's just say their show of appreciation became a running joke in the company.
reviews.pros:
Pros:
The coworkers are some of the nicest, well intentioned, true advocates of mental health you'll ever meet. 

Benefits are okay. Health plans are decent and they reimburse a lot of expenses. 

Pretty much it.
reviews.summary: Nice People but Horrible Expectations and Pay

reviews.advice: Complete overhaul of the culture.
reviews.cons: Everything is horrendous at Quartet
reviews.pros: Run! Do not work there. Management does not care about your well being.

reviews.cons: too much focus on brand over substance & products
reviews.pros: Fast paced environment; opportunities for growth and development.

reviews.advice: Promote from within and give people opportunities to grow. Listen to people with clinical backgrounds, and not just the clinical people from Innovatel. You don't even recognize the talent and knowledge that has been at Quartet for years because you don't ask, and that is a shame.
reviews.cons:
-More than anything, the biggest con is that leadership does not accept feedback. They are very defensive when faced with it, and I have heard many in the C suite laugh at how people at Quartet are "too sensitive" or "get offended by everything." They blame people for being unhappy and insist that's why the culture is bad.
-Decision makers do not have enough of a clinical background or lens to be successful in this type of company. When trying to figure out why patients aren't getting to care, they ignore the real reasons because they just want the quick fixes. They don't want to invest in fixing the tech or in making a positive experience for patients or providers. They just want to find the easiest, fastest thing they can present as a "solution" to investors and customers
-Leaders say to follow the data, but when presented with data that contradicts what they want to hear, the response is "Are you sure that's what it says? Let's pull it differently" until it aligns with their expectations.

It makes sense why leadership had to change and why Quartet focuses on just getting acquired. But they are so incredibly top heavy and filled with middle managers that I don't feel confident the company will reach that goal. They prioritize hiring old coworkers from Aspire to fill leadership roles, which is not only frustrating from a nepotism standpoint but it also means no opportunities for advancement for people who have been with the company and want to actually grow in their career. 

Unless you are coming from their white boys club in Nashville, I would not recommend joining at this time. Most of us are only still here while we actively look for other jobs.
reviews.pros:
-Some good people still at the company. If they are allowed to have their ideas heard and executed on, I think Quartet could pull off an acquisition. Also culturally there are some fun, smart people who are enjoyable to work alongside.
-Work/life balance can be really positive because expectations are low
-The mission is great
-Unlimited PTO
reviews.summary: New Strategy is Quantity over Quality

reviews.advice: Change doesn't happen in a day, but stay focused on what we commit to (to our team and our clients). Changing strategy is not always translated well to people's day to day, or thought through at that level. I agree with some of the other reviews that more questions should be asked of those actually doing the work prior to major changes.
reviews.cons:
- Like others said, Quartet recently hired groups of people from Aspire and similar places. I agree we should expand our horizons to keep adding diverse talent
-The 401(k) match should be increased
- Some of the leaders (high level, the managers are usually great) are better than others. My advice is to ask thoughtful questions about your executive leadership when interviewing here

None of these are dealbreakers for me, so I'm keeping my rating at 5 stars, but realistically it's probably between 4-5 stars based on some of the cons.
reviews.pros:
Quartet is one of many players in the health tech-enabled space. It's not for everyone, but I think it has a lot going for it. My experience at Quartet has had quite a few "pros."

- Smart and kind people across the board. Feeling like you can reach out to anyone with a question is paid lip service at other companies, but it's real here
- Inspiring mission, evolving strategy. Shifting strategy is frustrating, but the new strategy is objectively clearer, and I understand how we plan to make money with the new changes. Before...not so much 
- New, interesting challenges. This probably isn't true for every role or team, but I think my day-to-day is rich with new experiences
- I'm not patient-facing, so my view is limited, but I think we highlight our patient wins well and often. I love hearing about the indirect impact of my work on someone getting the care they need

I feel like you could throw a stone and hit 10 other companies "similar" to Quartet (Cerebral, Ginger, Alma, etc). I like what we're doing differently, the people, and my work, so it's a great match for me. Maybe it's not for you, but I'd take other reviews with a grain of salt and find out for yourself.
reviews.summary: Lots of change, but lots of positives as well

reviews.cons: No pay transparency within company. Lack of communication from higher up
reviews.pros: Good benefits, wonderful coworkers, good hours

reviews.advice: I appreciate that our CEO, Arun, is diligent about feedback and working hard to maintain transparency into what we do. I encourage all our upper management to follow his lead and be open to critique and improvement, because that's how we'll succeed as a company.
reviews.cons: Only major con is for the company to carefully scale upwards and not just expand in response to some external force. I know that with new clients and funding comes the itch to grow, but we must do so responsibly. We have to make sure to continue to bring in people that we have a place for, and not just hire to meet some quota. I think we're doing a good job with that now, but as we continue to expand let's be sure to keep the caliber high!
reviews.pros: I find myself incredibly impressed with the culture that Quartet has fostered. Here is a company that recognizes we're not trying to be a superficial app to make a quick buck, nor are we trying to be an over-the-top informal startup with scooters and ball pits. We're the right mix of formality (i.e. leadership that consists of former CEOs, upper management from the country's largest insurers and payers) that is important to help legitimize us to our clients and lean start-up (i.e. experienced engineers, data scientists, developers, technical staff from the startup world) who are driven by our personal connections to mental health in our own lives and our families. I find myself fulfilled in my job because of the varied and engaging work, along with the autonomy that is given which affirms the value of the employees.

reviews.advice: Keep the mission front and center for employees
reviews.cons: There are some growing pains, and Quartet has expanded very quickly while still trying to figure out how to maintain the dynamic that kept the company functioning smoothly when it was younger. More management training for new managers has been implemented, and it'll be important to see how that makes things better. The stakes are high as we're working directly with people's health, which must be balanced against the desire of the company to iterate quickly and experiment with new approaches where many employees don't come in from the healthcare industry. Greater reliance of health/clinical domain knowledge will allow Quartet to make decisions more relevant and beneficial to users.
reviews.pros: Quartet is tacking a critical problem in mental health, and has brought in a great team to do so. For many people here, mental health isn't something abstract. Sometimes it's substance abuse from a family member, sometimes a past experience with a broken healthcare system for depression. The personal connection from so many employees, from top to bottom, means that there's a sense that the products we're building must work and work well. I found it incredibly refreshing as it creates a culture of excellence, and it helps that you can directly see the impact of your work from the patient feedback we get every day. There's a lot of interest from insurance companies and provider groups about the work we do, and investors are recognizing the value that we bring.
reviews.summary: Working on an important mission with a great, committed group of people

reviews.advice: It feels like the company has lost its drive and its sense of purpose. The employees no longer feel inspired since David left as CEO.
reviews.cons: 401K matching is a joke; the mission of the organization changes constantly; the culture is non-existent at this point (early 2022)
reviews.pros: Have generally enjoyed working my coworkers; have been fortunate to have a very caring manager who wishes to see us succeed personally and professionally; mostly good benefits

reviews.cons: The whole job was very difficult and stressful I did not trust it
reviews.pros: The task and the ask not real. Felt like a scam very worried

reviews.cons: Terrible admin. Lie. Cheap. Likely bankrupt in 2 years. Poor fiscal management.
reviews.pros: None. None. None. None. None.
reviews.summary: Worst company I've ever worked for.

reviews.advice: Treat your employees like you use to. Most of the great talent has left or is going to leave. Why be the Walmart of digital health when you could be Target.
reviews.cons: In my time with the company they have slowly chipped away at the benefits package they offered. When I first started unlimited PTO was standard along with other great benefits. We recently have been told that we will no longer be receiving such a benefit. Along with that they have changed us from a salaried position to hourly. It is in my opinion that Quartet no longer cares about the employees who do the brunt of the work and are more about the bottom line. I’d think twice before apply here.
reviews.pros:
- Coworkers
- Working from home
- Mission Driven

reviews.cons: It's not a good place for you if you can't adapt to change.
reviews.pros: - Great people - Great opportunity for growth

reviews.cons: The con is also a pro in being remote. Its nice to work from home but you only get virtual interactions
reviews.pros: One team that works well together across all positions

reviews.advice: None! Continue working to promote transparency and a culture of One Team!
reviews.cons: None that I'm aware of at this time.
reviews.pros:
The company is very mission driven and you can feel that in every interaction. 
One of our core values is that we are One Team and you can truly feel that when working cross-functionally. 
Leadership has done an amazing job at taking previous feedback and implementing it to make them more available to employees by creating monthly office hours where employees can learn about what the strategy for that department looks like. 

In my 10+ years in the corporate world I can truly say that Quartet has been the best company I've ever worked for. I have never felt more valued in a corporate setting as I do at Quartet.

reviews.cons: Limited room for growth Benefits that are not aligned with rest of the company.
reviews.pros: Nice coworkers, remote work environment

reviews.cons: Management is mostly from traditional/large companies. Startup culture is slowly fading. Hiring for non-clinical roles has dried up.
reviews.pros: Has been an exciting place to work since its acquisition last year of Innovatel. Lots of new opportunities and initiatives that feel like we're heading in the right directions. Culture is very strongly positive.

reviews.cons: Quartet is struggling to find product market fit. Some of its products are useful and impactful , some are a solution in search of a problem.
reviews.pros: Small company , ability to make a big impact , learn a lot , and take charge of features / bug fixes. I generally liked all the people i worked with , especially the other engineers , but everyone else was hard working and cared about the mission. I don’t have a lot bad to say about the company . WLB was excellent. If you’re an early career engineer that wants to work on a mature product that still has a lot of feature work available, start here

reviews.cons: Consistently re-organizing and re-structuring; loyalty not rewarded; current CEO (Puneet Singh) and other leadership failed to push the envelope, innovate, retain customers, or derive any profit; strong decline in company culture; lack of/minimal 401K matching
reviews.pros: Great work-life balance; good health insurance coverage; excellent mental health resources

reviews.cons: No L&D or benefits for learning,
reviews.pros: Committed leadership, good people overall

reviews.cons: Frequent management change and reorgs
reviews.pros: Lot of opportunities to grow

reviews.cons: There are no cons for me.
reviews.pros: The work environment is great. You have access to speak to senior leadership on a monthly basis and everyone is super friendly and willing to help. Remote work environment. Alot of work life balance and awesome benefits. The company really cares about it's employees.

reviews.cons: A lot of changes that aren’t benefiting the employees
reviews.pros: The team is really great

reviews.cons: It always seemed like ever changing business priorities
reviews.pros: Quartet pays very competitively for salary

reviews.cons: none at all! enjoy . its great
reviews.pros: great work environment for all

reviews.cons: low salary, low bonus, many hours
reviews.pros: good people to work with

reviews.advice: It’s truly unfortunate that Quartet is going downhill. Loss of salaries and benefits overnight with no warning, lack of transparency from the top down, and no accountability for the impact of layoffs. Many gave clear feedback during the last round of layoffs, which was completely disregarded by leadership yet again. The company does not value our efforts to make it easier for patients to connect to care. They are just focused on making money at this point, and it’s disappointing to see them cut corners to try to accomplish this. Truly unfortunate.
reviews.cons: -Limited to no opportunities for growth and development -Lack of transparency from leadership (even when they say that this is something they are working on) -Complete shift of company priorities to care delivery with no phase out plan for care connections -Regular abrupt layoffs
reviews.pros: -Remote work -Coworkers (incredible talent here) -Opportunity to directly improve outcomes for some patients

reviews.cons: limited opportunity for professional growth
reviews.pros: it has a chill work environment

reviews.advice: Grow up. Listen to your employees. Let them know that they’re heard. Listen to your employees. Care about your employees. Listen to your employees.
reviews.cons: This company is inevitably sinking and no one wants to admit it. The management of the care navigation team is absolutely horrible. The managers have one way meetings and don’t allow care navigators or care support specialists to have voices. The team members are not allowed to ask questions during meetings and are told that if they do have questions to please go to their managers in their one-on-one meetings in private. Meanwhile, all of the Care navigation members talk crap about the managers in private slack groups. The morale of the team is incredibly low, the turnover rate is extremely high, and the managers “have no idea why.” When I started with quartet, the benefits were amazing and the morale of the team was high. But, gradually, the benefits have been taken away from the care navigation team and the work life balance absolutely sucks. Oh, but don’t worry, Care navigation managers get to keep their unlimited PTO, salaried wages, and great benefits. It’s in anyone and everyone’s best interest to avoid this sinking ship of a company. They have a great mission but they do an absolutely horrible job of executing it to patients in need of mental health services. Also, the cost of living has gone up and there’s been an increase in job responsibilities for the care navigation team, yet no increase in salary. If you’re looking for a job, look elsewhere. Trust me.

If you want to feel like the sludge at the bottom of a pond, join Quartet!
reviews.pros: The pros are pretty simple, you work from home. Which in all honesty isn’t such a pro anymore with so many companies offering this. That’s the only pro.
reviews.summary: Quartet Health; the mental health company that cares NOTHING about mental health!

reviews.advice: Treat your employees like you use to. Most of the great talent has left or is going to leave. Why be the Walmart of digital health when you could be Target.
reviews.cons: In my time with the company they have slowly chipped away at the benefits package they offered. When I first started unlimited PTO was standard along with other great benefits. We recently have been told that we will no longer be receiving such a benefit. Along with that they have changed us from a salaried position to hourly. It is in my opinion that Quartet no longer cares about the employees who do the brunt of the work and are more about the bottom line. I’d think twice before apply here.

reviews.advice: Grow up. Listen to your employees. Let them know that they’re heard. Listen to your employees. Care about your employees. Listen to your employees.
reviews.cons: This company is inevitably sinking and no one wants to admit it. The management of the care navigation team is absolutely horrible. The managers have one way meetings and don’t allow care navigators or care support specialists to have voices. The team members are not allowed to ask questions during meetings and are told that if they do have questions to please go to their managers in their one-on-one meetings in private. Meanwhile, all of the Care navigation members talk crap about the managers in private slack groups. The morale of the team is incredibly low, the turnover rate is extremely high, and the managers “have no idea why.” When I started with quartet, the benefits were amazing and the morale of the team was high. But, gradually, the benefits have been taken away from the care navigation team and the work life balance absolutely sucks. Oh, but don’t worry, Care navigation managers get to keep their unlimited PTO, salaried wages, and great benefits. It’s in anyone and everyone’s best interest to avoid this sinking ship of a company. They have a great mission but they do an absolutely horrible job of executing it to patients in need of mental health services. Also, the cost of living has gone up and there’s been an increase in job responsibilities for the care navigation team, yet no increase in salary. If you’re looking for a job, look elsewhere. Trust me.

# [Quartet Health Launches Innovative Whole Health Program to Improve Outcomes for Patients with Serious Mental Illness on 2024-03-19](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/)
Partnership with Clover Health Supports Underserved Patient Population With a New Whole-Person Care Delivery Solution

Quartet Health, a leading value-based behavioral health care enablement and delivery company, today launched their Whole Health program in partnership with Clover Health, a physician enablement company, to better serve patients living with serious mental illnesses (SMI). The first-of-its-kind, whole-person care delivery solution is the only fully integrated physical and behavioral health model that takes accountability for the total cost of care (TCOC) risk on health plans’ most complex members, while also providing wraparound care services for a traditionally underserved patient population. The program was launched first in the New Jersey market.

“Patients with serious mental illness often have worse outcomes and a lower life expectancy, and they experience a fragmented healthcare system that does not adequately address their behavioral, physical, and social needs” said Dr. Michael J. Lipp, Quartet Health’s Chief Medical Officer, and former CMO of the CMS Innovation Center. Clover Health’s members with SMI average at least four different chronic conditions, with more than five different providers prescribing medications. Additionally, one in five members with SMI did not see a primary care physician (PCP) last year, and one in three did not see a behavioral health provider. “Patients often struggle to get access to care, and the care they do receive is often uncoordinated. This program will provide care that is coordinated, comprehensive and convenient, at no additional cost to patients.”

The partnership with Clover Health gives Quartet Health the opportunity to address the unique needs of this complex patient population with a health equity-based focus, through 24/7 care access, medication support, mental and physical care coordination, as well as local community resource and transportation support. Care teams – both in-market and virtual – will be led by nurse practitioners, trained in both mental health and family medicine, along with care coordinators, social workers, case managers, therapists, peers, and supervising psychiatrists and internal medicine physicians.

“For far too long, behavioral healthcare solutions for individuals living with SMI have not adequately accounted for the interconnectedness of both their physical and mental health needs,” said Christina Mainelli, Quartet Health CEO. “Patients are often forced to navigate an incredibly fragmented healthcare system, a system that fails to meet their needs, contributes to unnecessary hospitalizations and, ultimately, worse outcomes. That’s why it was so critical for us, in developing our Whole Health program, to take an approach that treats the whole person in a way that improves quality and patient outcomes, while also lowering the cost of care.”

“We’re confident that additional behavioral health support for our SMI cohort will increase the quality of life for these members, while continuing to reduce unnecessary spend,” said Brady Priest, CEO of Clover Home Care.

# [Senior Actuarial Analyst - Quartet Health](https://www.builtinnyc.com/job/actuary/286127)
About Quartet Health

Quartet is a purpose driven value-based behavioral healthcare company, building the nation’s leading behavioral health home. We deliver integrated care and better outcomes to improve the health of communities across America. Quartet is a trusted partner of health insurance plans, health systems, community behavioral health centers, certified community behavioral health clinics, and federally qualified health centers in 36 states across the country. We identify people in need of care and connect them directly to high quality behavioral care providers, including Quartet’s own medical group.

At Quartet, our values guide the way that we work together, starting with our commitment to putting patients first, and our shared focus on collaboration and innovation, so that we – together – can improve lives, one person at a time.

Quartet is backed by top investors like Oak HC/FT, GV (formerly Google Ventures), F-Prime Capital Partners, Polaris Partners, Deerfield Management, Centene Corporation, Independence Health Group, and Echo Health Ventures.

About the Role

We are seeking a skilled Senior Actuarial Analyst to join our team. The ideal candidate will have experience in actuarial analysis, particularly within the healthcare or insurance industry, and exposure to Medicare Advantage is a plus.

Role Responsibilities

Conduct actuarial analysis to support various business functions.

Data Analysis: Perform data analysis to support actuarial assumptions and decision-making processes.

Assist in the preparation and analysis of financial reports.

Forecasting and Budgeting: Support financial forecasting and budgeting efforts.

Work with cross-functional teams to support business objectives.

Ensure compliance with relevant regulations and guidelines.

Identify opportunities for process improvements and implement best practices in actuarial methodologies.

In your first 90 days: Begin to conduct basic actuarial analyses and data analyses, gaining a foundational understanding of key business functions and financial reporting requirements while starting to support team efforts.

Within your first 6 months: Start to contribute to financial forecasting and budgeting processes with guidance, work effectively with cross-functional teams on assigned tasks, and ensure adherence to basic regulatory requirements while learning about actuarial methodologies.

Future success: Develop a solid grasp of actuarial processes, gradually identify and suggest improvements, and contribute to supporting business objectives and regulatory compliance as you build expertise and take on more complex responsibilities.

Required Qualifications

A bachelor’s degree in Actuarial Science, Mathematics, Statistics, or a related field.

A minimum of 3 years of actuarial experience, preferably in the healthcare or insurance industry.

You are pursuing Associate of the Society of Actuaries (ASA) designation..

You have experience with financial forecasting and budgeting.

Preferred Qualifications

You have a proficient level of programming skills, such as in SQL or R

Expert user of Excel

Proficiency in python programming

Consulting and/or Client management experience

Our Benefits

​We're proud to offer the following benefits to our team members:

Fully remote work environment

A​ flexible PTO policy and paid holidays

Paid parental leave

​R​obust medical, dental and vision insurance plans

A 401​(k​) plan with employer match

Mental health benefits

100% employer-paid life insurance​, short-term and long-term disability insurance

​Annual learning & development budge​t

Compensation:

A reasonable estimate of the base salary range for this role is $108,000 to $132,000, with an additional annual bonus target percentage.

The final compensation for this role is based on several factors including, but not limited to, type of position, location, education level, work experience, and certifications.

Quartet actively encourages applicants of all backgrounds to apply and is proud to be an equal opportunity employer. We do not discriminate on the basis of race, color, ancestry, religion, national origin, sexual orientation, age, citizenship, marital or family status, disability, gender, gender identity or expression, pregnancy or caregiver status, veteran status, or any other legally protected status. To perform this job successfully, an individual must be able to perform essential job duties - reasonable accommodations may be made to enable qualified individuals with disabilities to perform essential job functions. If you require assistance in completing this application, interviewing, or otherwise participating in the employee selection process, please direct your inquiries to [email protected]

The VBC Provider Operations Manager will develop strong working relationships with behavioral health practices and providers (BHPs) with the goal of setting BHPs up for success in utilizing Quartet’s products and services to achieve target VBC goals as part of client partnerships.

Work creatively in navigating and overcoming obstacles, partnering with stakeholders and relevant internal team members to reduce barriers to success and mitigate risks

# Comprehensive Analyst Report on Quartet Health

## Company Overview

Quartet Health is a value-based behavioral healthcare company focused on delivering integrated care to improve health outcomes across the United States. The company partners with health insurance plans, health systems, community behavioral health centers, certified community behavioral health clinics, and federally qualified health centers in 36 states [(Tracxn, 2021-08-17)](https://tracxn.com/d/companies/quartet-health/__h0aWquU4iWJlxJchzH5LBsnUHhqRtzgJV8zFxkNd9ek). Quartet aims to identify individuals in need of care and connect them with high-quality behavioral health providers, including its own medical group [(Built In NYC, 2023)](https://www.builtinnyc.com/job/actuary/286127).

The company is backed by prominent investors such as Oak HC/FT, GV (formerly Google Ventures), F-Prime Capital Partners, and Centene Corporation, indicating strong financial support and confidence in its business model [(Built In NYC, 2023)](https://www.builtinnyc.com/job/actuary/286127).

## Recent Developments

On March 19, 2024, Quartet Health announced the launch of its Whole Health program in partnership with Clover Health. This innovative program is designed to provide a comprehensive care delivery solution for patients with serious mental illnesses (SMI) by integrating physical and behavioral health services. The initiative aims to address the fragmented healthcare system that often leads to poor outcomes for these patients [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).

Dr. Michael J. Lipp, Quartet Health’s Chief Medical Officer, emphasized the need for coordinated care, stating, “Patients often struggle to get access to care, and the care they do receive is often uncoordinated. This program will provide care that is coordinated, comprehensive and convenient, at no additional cost to patients” [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).

## Product Overview

The Whole Health program is a first-of-its-kind initiative that takes accountability for the total cost of care (TCOC) risk on health plans’ most complex members. It provides wraparound care services, including 24/7 access to care, medication support, and coordination of mental and physical health services [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/). This program is particularly focused on underserved populations, addressing the unique needs of patients with SMI who often have multiple chronic conditions and face barriers to accessing care [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).

Christina Mainelli, CEO of Quartet Health, highlighted the importance of this integrated approach, stating, “For far too long, behavioral healthcare solutions for individuals living with SMI have not adequately accounted for the interconnectedness of both their physical and mental health needs” [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).

## Company Scale and Operations

Quartet Health operates a significant network across the United States, with a focus on improving the health of communities through integrated care. The company’s operational model is designed to enhance collaboration among various healthcare providers and ensure that patients receive comprehensive care tailored to their needs [(Built In NYC, 2023)](https://www.builtinnyc.com/job/actuary/286127).

## Executive Leadership

The leadership team at Quartet Health includes experienced professionals from various healthcare backgrounds. Dr. Michael J. Lipp, as Chief Medical Officer, brings expertise from his previous role as CMO of the CMS Innovation Center, which adds credibility to the company's initiatives in value-based care [(Quartet Health, 2024-03-19)](https://www.quartethealth.com/perspectives/quartet-health-launches-innovative-whole-health-program-to-improve-outcomes-for-patients-with-serious-mental-illness/).

## Conclusion

Quartet Health is positioned as a leader in the behavioral healthcare space, particularly with its recent launch of the Whole Health program in partnership with Clover Health. The company's commitment to integrated care and addressing the needs of underserved populations reflects a strong alignment with current healthcare trends focused on value-based care. For prospective candidates and investors, Quartet Health represents an opportunity to engage with a forward-thinking organization dedicated to improving health outcomes through innovative solutions. 

For further details, please refer to the original sources cited throughout this report.
